title: AI Is the Social Media for Engineering
description: AI can either compound your understanding or quietly erode it, depending on whether you treat it like a tool or a feed.
contentMarkdown:
## Input Feels Like Progress

We live in an era of infinite input.

Articles, tweets, videos, podcasts, newsletters, and now AI responses stream toward us all day. Much of it is genuinely insightful. That is the trap.

Input does not equal learning.

Learning requires friction. It requires sitting with an idea long enough to integrate it into your existing mental models. It requires trying, failing, and correcting. Most people skip that part. Instead, they consume the next thing.

Cognitive science backs this up. Research on attention and learning shows that passive consumption leads to shallow processing and poor long-term retention, especially when information arrives rapidly and without effortful recall.

An analogy helps here.

Reading a recipe does not mean you know how to cook the dish.

You only learn once you try to make it in your own kitchen, with your own tools, and fix what goes wrong. Most people are just reading recipes all day and wondering why they never improve.

---

## Dopamine, Feeds, and Fragmented Attention

Short-form content makes this worse.

YouTube contains some of the most educational material ever created. Yet ask yourself a blunt question: can you name one concrete thing you learned from the last video you watched?

Social media is even more extreme. It is optimized for dopamine, not understanding. Fast context switching fragments attention, and fragmented attention kills deep learning.

Studies consistently show that frequent task switching and digital distraction reduce comprehension, working memory capacity, and the ability to sustain focus.

Now layer AI on top of this.

AI is an incredible tool for engineering and learning. It can speed up feedback loops, expose blind spots, and help you reason through complex problems. Used well, it is a multiplier.

Used poorly, it becomes social media for engineers.

Endless, polished, agreeable responses. Suggestions that nudge you to ask just one more question. Branching ideas that split your attention. Code that works but is poorly suited to your actual problem. Explanations that feel satisfying but never force you to think.

The danger is subtle. With social media, we know we are wasting time. With AI, it feels productive. You think you are learning or engineering, when in reality you are skimming solutions you do not understand.

If you are not actively counteracting this, AI will happily give you:

- Code you cannot explain  
- Designs you did not reason through  
- Answers that sound good but are not optimal  
- A false sense of competence  

That is how engineers get worse, not better.

---

## Treat AI Like a Tool, Not a Feed

The fix is not to avoid AI. It is to change how you use it.

AI is only as good as the structure you impose on it.

### 1. Change the Instructions

Default AI behavior is optimized for engagement and politeness. Override it.

Tell it to be direct. Tell it to challenge you. Tell it to reason from first principles. Remove the social lubricant.

If you do not do this, you will get generic, pleasing output by default.

### 2. Separate Learning From Execution

If you are learning:

- Tell the model to ask you questions  
- Use Socratic reasoning  
- Have it quiz you  
- Force yourself to answer before seeing solutions  

Do not rob yourself of the learning loop. Struggle is part of the process.

If you are engineering:

- Provide a clear outline  
- Be explicit about constraints  
- Share what you have already tried  
- Ask it to identify tradeoffs, not just solutions  

Vagueness produces slop.

### 3. Slow the Interaction Down

Rapid prompting feels productive but fractures attention.

Pause. Read the response carefully. Summarize it in your own words. Modify it. Test it. Break it. Fix it.

This is the equivalent of cooking the recipe instead of bookmarking it.

### 4. Do Some Work Without AI

This matters more than people want to admit.

If you never reason through problems on your own, your internal models atrophy. AI should extend your thinking, not replace it.

The more you understand the problem space, the better AI performs. High-quality input produces high-quality output. Shallow understanding produces homogeneous junk.

---

## Closing: Engineering Still Requires Depth

AI does not make engineers better by default.

Used lazily, it does the same thing YouTube does to learning. It creates the illusion of progress while eroding focus and understanding.

Used deliberately, it is one of the most powerful tools we have ever had.

The difference is discipline.

Software engineering has always rewarded deep work, clear thinking, and the ability to reason through complexity. AI does not change that. It amplifies it, for better or worse.

Treat AI like social media, and it will make you dumber.  
Treat it like a tool, and it will make you dangerous.

---
